issues.description: Whether the district court erred in finding at summary judgment that Jack in the Box's (JITB) overdeductions from the Workers’ Benefit Fund (WBF) were willful, thus justifying penalty wages
issues.key_reasoning: The court held that a reasonable jury could find JITB did not have full knowledge of the overdeductions and that the error was an unintentional miscalculation, so summary judgment on willfulness was improper and a trial is required.

issues.description: Whether the district court abused its discretion in allowing Plaintiffs to present the 'Late Final Pay 1' penalty wage theory at trial despite an earlier ruling suggesting waiver
issues.key_reasoning: The court found the later judge properly reconsidered the prior ruling, concluding Plaintiffs did not waive the theory and allowing it did not prejudice JITB.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in its constitutional due process analysis of the penalty wage award
issues.key_reasoning: The district court failed to consider that penalty wages are punitive rather than compensatory and ignored the disproportionate ratio between statutory penalty wages and actual damages; these errors require reassessment on remand.

issues.description: Whether the district court abused its discretion by declining to exclude class members whose mailed notices were undeliverable
issues.key_reasoning: The court found the district court provided the best practicable notice under the circumstances and that JITB failed to show alternative methods or prejudice.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in refusing to reduce prejudgment interest due to Plaintiffs’ alleged delays in prosecuting the case
issues.key_reasoning: Oregon law mandates prejudgment interest as a matter of right once damages are ascertainable, and the district court correctly found no discretion to reduce interest for delays.

issues.description: Whether the court has jurisdiction over Plaintiffs’ cross-appeal challenging unpaid break claims
issues.key_reasoning: Because the district court granted JITB’s Rule 50(b) motion and entered an amended judgment, the 30-day appeal period runs from the amended judgment, making the cross-appeal timely.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in refusing to certify an unpaid break class based on individualized inquiries about reasons for shortened breaks
issues.key_reasoning: Although the Oregon Court of Appeals in Maza held reasons for shortened breaks do not matter, the district court correctly found that the relevant regulation requiring pay for shortened breaks only applied after June 2010, after all named Plaintiffs left JITB, so certification was improper.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in granting JITB’s renewed motion for judgment as a matter of law on the named Plaintiffs’ individual unpaid break claims
issues.key_reasoning: Plaintiffs waived their breach of contract theory based on On-Duty Meal Policy Agreements by not raising it below and expressly disclaiming it, so JMOL was proper.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in granting partial summary judgment to JITB on its affirmative defense that shoe deductions were for employees’ benefit
issues.key_reasoning: A reasonable jury could find that the shoe requirement primarily benefited JITB through rebates and indemnities rather than employees, so the benefit defense was improperly decided on summary judgment.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in decertifying the shoe class and whether written authorization is a defense to the minimum wage and overtime shoe claims
issues.key_reasoning: Because the benefit issue must be retried, the district court should reconsider class certification; also, written authorization is not a defense to the minimum wage and overtime claims under Oregon law, so the district court erred in applying it.

issues.description: Whether the district court erred in overriding the jury verdict on Plaintiffs’ individual shoe claims
issues.key_reasoning: The jury found written authorization but awarded penalty wages under the minimum wage statute where written authorization is not a defense; the district court erred in reducing the award.

key_precedents: Wilson v. Smurfit Newsprint Corp., 197 Or. App. 648 (2005)
Maza v. Waterford Operations, LLC, 300 Or. App. 471 (2019)
Taylor v. Werner Enters., Inc., 329 Or. 461 (1999)
Wakefield v. ViSalus, Inc., 51 F.4th 1109 (9th Cir. 2022)
Roes, 1-2 v. SFBSC Mgmt., LLC, 944 F.3d 1035 (9th Cir. 2019)
Lierboe v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 350 F.3d 1018 (9th Cir. 2003)
summary_text:
Wage and Hour Claims / Oregon Law

The panel reversed in part and affirmed in part the district court’s judgment in a wage-and-hour case brought by plaintiffs against their former employer, Jack in the Box (JITB), on behalf of themselves and a class of other former employees.
Plaintiffs challenged three JITB policies: JITB overdeducted its employees’ wages for the Oregon Workers’ Benefit Fund (WBF), JITB did not pay workers for interrupted meal periods more than 20 minutes long, and JITB deducted employees’ pay for non-slip shoes.
Plaintiffs prevailed on the WBF claims, and JITB defeated the unpaid break and shoe claims. JITB appealed, and plaintiffs cross-appealed. The panel reversed the district court’s judgment on the WBF and shoe claims, and remanded, and affirmed the district court’s judgment on the unpaid break claims.
Addressing JITB’s appeal concerning the WBF overdeductions, the panel held that the district court erred in finding, at summary judgment, that JITB’s overdeductions were willful such that JITB owed penalty wages, and remanded for a trial on willfulness. To help the district court and the parties retry the case, the panel also provided guidance on a penalty wage theory the parties call “Late Final Pay 1”—a claim for penalty wages for WBF overdeductions but not minimum wage or overtime violations—and the constitutional limits on penalty wages.
Next, the panel held that the district court did not abuse its discretion in declining to exclude the class members whose mailed notices were undeliverable, nor did the district court err in refusing to reduce the prejudgment interest for plaintiffs’ alleged delays. However, on remand, the district court will have to recalculate the prejudgment interest in light of the holding on willfulness.
Addressing plaintiffs’ cross-appeal, the panel held that it had jurisdiction. Because the district court granted JITB’s Fed. R. Civ. P. 50(b) motion, the 30-day deadline of Fed. R. App. P. 4(a)(1)(A) ran from the amended judgment, and the cross-appeal was timely.
The panel rejected plaintiffs’ challenges to how the district court’s rulings on their unpaid break claims. First, the district court did not abuse its discretion in refusing to certify the unpaid break class. Second, the district court did not err in granting JITB’s renewed motion for judgment as a matter of law on the named plaintiffs’ individual claims because plaintiffs waived the theory that they could prevail individually by proving JITB breached its On-Duty Meal Policy Agreements with plaintiffs.
The panel reversed the district court’s judgment on the shoe claims. The panel held that the district court erred in granting partial summary judgment to JITB on its affirmative defense that the shoe deductions were for its employees’ benefit, and reversed and remanded so a jury can decide whether the shoe requirement was for the employees’ benefit. The panel also remanded so the district court can reconsider whether to certify the shoe class.
